etymology.description: phonetic 敝 + semantic 巾 (“towel/cloth”); simplified from 幣 (敝 → 丿)
etymology.interpretation: Originally indicated cloth used as offerings or gifts, which extended to the idea of currency. 敝 supplied the sound while also evoking cloth, and 巾 provided the semantic field; the simplification reduced 敝 to a single stroke, weakening the phonetic cue.
etymology.simplification: Reduced strokes by replacing the complex phonetic 敝 with the single stroke 丿, largely preserving only the cloth-derived semantic hint.

examples.chinese: 我们需要稳定的货币来发展经济(我們需要穩定的貨幣來發展經濟)。
examples.pinyin: Wǒmen xūyào wěndìng de huòbì lái fāzhǎn jīngjì.
examples.english: We need stable currency to develop the economy.

examples.chinese: 他把外币换成人民币(他把外幣換成人民幣)。
examples.pinyin: Tā bǎ wàibì huàn chéng Rénmínbì.
examples.english: He exchanged foreign currency for renminbi.

examples.chinese: 旅行前准备一些小面额的纸币比较方便(旅行前準備一些小面額的紙幣比較方便)。
examples.pinyin: Lǚxíng qián zhǔnbèi yīxiē xiǎo miàn'é de zhǐbì bǐjiào fāngbiàn.
examples.english: It is more convenient to prepare some small-denomination banknotes before traveling.
